text:
Hi all, I’d like to present a small experimental compiler package I’ve been working on which some of you may find fun to experiment with:

<https://discourse.julialang.org/t/ann-mixtape-jl-a-static-overlay-and-optimization-tool/58979>

attachments.title: ANN: Mixtape.jl -- a static overlay and optimization tool
attachments.text: Hi all – I’d like to present a small experimental compiler package I’ve been working on with the help of AbstractInterpreter and GPUCompiler (as well as the sick, twisted minds of @vchuravy and @Roger-luo). Here’s the value proposition: Mixtape.jl is a static method overlay and optimization tool which operates during Julia type inference. It allows you to (precisely) insert semantic-intruding changes to lowered code (e.g. replace CodeInfo , pre-optimize CodeInfo , and create other forms of s...
attachments.fallback: JuliaLang: ANN: Mixtape.jl -- a static overlay and optimization tool

text: Yeah, those “sick, twisted” minds are the best! :slightly_smiling_face:

text: (anybody who can come up with a package like Cthulhu.jl is a star in my mind, and the Roger’s work on mind-bending quantum stuff is also wonderful)

text:
Looks awesome! (and :mind_blown: )

Since it’s already using GPUCompiler.jl, would there be a reasonable pathway to producing static binaries?

elements.text:
)

Since it’s already using GPUCompiler.jl, would there be a reasonable pathway to producing static binaries?

text: <@UGU761DU2> that would be a particularly interesting and compelling use case — if I know more about it. I have not studied StaticCompiler at all, I’d likely have to look there first.

elements.text: that would be a particularly interesting and compelling use case — if I know more about it. I have not studied StaticCompiler at all, I’d likely have to look there first.

text: <@U69BK8S74> wonder if you have any comments here (in the relationship between GPUCompiler’s linked in OrcJIT and StaticCompiler — and how feasible it might be to compile a binary given something which works with GPUCompiler)

text: would it be possible to use this to implement something like a switch statement or computed goto or am I not understanding it very well?

text: I’m not sure I understand your question — do you mean extend the set of code nodes/stmt on CodeInfo?

text:
I meant it looks I could look for patterns like
```if a == 1
  call_1()
elseif a == 2
  call_2()
elseif a == 3
  ...```
and replace it with code that would use indirectbr to do this instead.  I can generate code to do this for specific cases like here:
```Base.@ccallable Nothing function foo1()
    println("1")
    return nothing
end

Base.@ccallable Nothing function foo2()
    println("2")
    return nothing
end

Base.@ccallable Nothing function foo3()
    println("3")
    return nothing
end

function dofoo(x::Int32)
    Core.Intrinsics.llvmcall(("""
        declare void @foo1()
        declare void @foo2()
        declare void @foo3()
        define i8* @dofoo(i32 %idx) nounwind {
        %labels = alloca [6 x i8*]
        %da = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 0
        %db = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 1
        %dc = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 2
        %dd = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 3
        %de = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 4
        %df = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 5
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %AA), i8** %da
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %BB), i8** %db
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %CC), i8** %dc
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %DD), i8** %dd
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %EE), i8** %de
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %FF), i8** %df
        %brtoptr = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 %idx
        %brto = load i8*, i8** %brtoptr
        indirectbr i8* %brto, [label %AA, label %BB, label %CC, label %DD, label %EE, label %FF]
        AA:
        call void @foo1()
        ret i8* %brto
        BB:
        call void @foo2()
        ret i8* %brto
        CC:
        call void @foo3()
        ret i8* %brto
        DD:
        call void @foo3()
        ret i8* %brto
        EE:
        call void @foo2()
        ret i8* %brto
        FF:
        call void @foo1()
        ret i8* %brto
        }
    """,
        """
        %2 = call i8* @dofoo(i32 %0)
        %3 = ptrtoint i8* %2 to i64
        ret i64 %3
    """), Int64, Tuple{Int32}, x)
end

let
    dofoo(Int32(2));
end```
but I don't know how to do this in general in a nice way.

elements.text: I meant it looks I could look for patterns like

if a == 1
  call_1()
elseif a == 2
  call_2()
elseif a == 3
  ...
and replace it with code that would use indirectbr to do this instead.  I can generate code to do this for specific cases like here:

Base.@ccallable Nothing function foo1()
    println("1")
    return nothing
end

Base.@ccallable Nothing function foo2()
    println("2")
    return nothing
end

Base.@ccallable Nothing function foo3()
    println("3")
    return nothing
end

function dofoo(x::Int32)
    Core.Intrinsics.llvmcall(("""
        declare void @foo1()
        declare void @foo2()
        declare void @foo3()
        define i8* @dofoo(i32 %idx) nounwind {
        %labels = alloca [6 x i8*]
        %da = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 0
        %db = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 1
        %dc = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 2
        %dd = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 3
        %de = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 4
        %df = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 5
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %AA), i8** %da
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %BB), i8** %db
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %CC), i8** %dc
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %DD), i8** %dd
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %EE), i8** %de
        store i8* blockaddress(@dofoo, %FF), i8** %df
        %brtoptr = getelementptr [6 x i8*], [6 x i8*]* %labels, i32 0, i32 %idx
        %brto = load i8*, i8** %brtoptr
        indirectbr i8* %brto, [label %AA, label %BB, label %CC, label %DD, label %EE, label %FF]
        AA:
        call void @foo1()
        ret i8* %brto
        BB:
        call void @foo2()
        ret i8* %brto
        CC:
        call void @foo3()
        ret i8* %brto
        DD:
        call void @foo3()
        ret i8* %brto
        EE:
        call void @foo2()
        ret i8* %brto
        FF:
        call void @foo1()
        ret i8* %brto
        }
    """,
        """
        %2 = call i8* @dofoo(i32 %0)
        %3 = ptrtoint i8* %2 to i64
        ret i64 %3
    """), Int64, Tuple{Int32}, x)
end

let
    dofoo(Int32(2));
end
but I don't know how to do this in general in a nice way.
